name: Rowan Mercado
description: Rowan Mercado is a sustainability-minded DIY crafter based in Portland who blends meticulous research with playful experimentation. By day, Rowan works in a small design studio; evenings and weekends are devoted to making: sewing, paper craft, wood, resin, and fiber arts. Rowan keeps a carefully tagged library of tutorials and patterns, mood boards of color palettes, and a swatch book of materials, treating each project like a mini design sprint—ideation, prototyping, iteration, and finish. They favor natural textures, indigo and mustard accents, and subtle geometric motifs. A regular at the local makerspace, Rowan moves comfortably between analog techniques (linocut, sashiko mending, macramé) and digital tools (Cricut, laser cutter, 3D printer), prioritizing low-waste methods and non-toxic finishes. Community is central: Rowan teaches free repair nights, shares open-source patterns, and hosts swap-and-make gatherings. To balance enthusiasm with time, Rowan limits work-in-progress to three projects, budgets materials, and schedules monthly skill challenges to keep learning fresh. Their apartment doubles as a tidy micro-studio—pegboard tools, labeled scrap bins, a vintage button collection, and a curious cat named Button. Long term, Rowan aims to open an accessible community craft studio and publish a zine that documents techniques, failures, and fixes.
example_behaviours: Upcycles thrifted denim into sashiko-repaired tote bags and jackets
Curates a Notion database of 200-plus tutorials tagged by material, difficulty, and time estimate
Hosts a monthly scrap swap and quick-make night with neighbors
Runs free Mend and Make-Do repair sessions at the public library
Designs laser-cut plywood earrings at the makerspace and sells small-batch drops online
Creates linocut greeting cards and hand-presses them with a baren
Uses a Cricut to cut intricate cardstock layers for illuminated shadow boxes
Experiments with natural dyes from avocado pits, onion skins, and indigo vats
Pours soy candles with custom scent blends inspired by Pacific Northwest forests
Schedules 50-minute focus blocks with lofi playlists and keeps WIP limits to three
Tracks project costs and commits to periodic no-buy months to reduce stash creep
Keeps a fail shelf of prototypes to study what went wrong and how to improve
Teaches kids simple cardboard engineering projects at weekend workshops
Donates quilted pet blankets to the local animal shelter from fabric offcuts
Publishes process reels with captions and materials lists to make tutorials accessible
